TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit TextView extends System.Web.UI.MobileControls.PagedControl

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("The System.Web.Mobile.dll assembly has been deprecated and should no longer be used. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=157231.")

Docs.summary: Provides a programmable control for displaying larger amounts of text, with optional markup tags on a mobile page. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Unlike literal text in a mobile form, you can set content of a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView> from code. Unlike a mobile <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Label> control, you can include markup within the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView.Text%2A> property. Also, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView> control is careful not to break up inserted elements such as links during pagination. For more information, see [Literal Text Inside Form Markup](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/05e061ed-9916-4ece-bfc8-7bf131fe232e).
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView> control is within a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel>, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel.Paginate%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property to `true` to allow text to flow across multiple pages on mobile devices. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView> control is not in a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel>, put the name of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView> control into the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.ControlToPaginate%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property.
Most other properties and methods of the mobile <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView> control are of more use to developers of new device adapters for rendering the contents on specific devices.
> [!CAUTION] > This control can be used to display user input, which might include malicious client script. Check any information that is sent from a client for executable script, SQL statements, or other code before displaying it in your application. You can use validation controls to verify user input before displaying the input text in a control. ASP.NET provides an input request validation feature to block script and HTML in user input. For more information, see [Securing Standard Controls](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/f3e7718f-63d0-44a3-bd5f-48cc2059c2a8), [How to: Protect Against Script Exploits in a Web Application by Applying HTML Encoding to Strings](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/6f67973f-dda0-45a1-ba9d-e88532d7dc5b), and [Validating User Input in ASP.NET Web Pages](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/4ad3dacb-89e0-4cee-89ac-40a3f2a85461).
## Examples The following code example creates numbers and identifies each prime number in a sentence, and adds those sentences to the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView> control. The example also uses custom pagination to provide only a page full of text at a time.
> [!NOTE] > The following code sample uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code sample must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Code Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/81b13e7a-b95b-4285-906f-d2dd77411417).
[!code-aspx-csharp[MobileTextViewSample#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileTextViewSample/cs/Default.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[MobileTextViewSample#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileTextViewSample/vb/Default.aspx#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int ItemsPerPage { int get(); void set(int value); };
member this.ItemsPerPage : int with get, set

Docs.summary: Sets or returns the number of items displayed per page after pagination. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.
Docs.value: The number of items displayed per page after pagination.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView.ItemsPerPage%2A> property is used by developers of custom device adapters for rendering the contents.
If zero, pagination is not affected by this property. If nonzero, overrides items displayed per page when the form is paginated. The default value is zero.
Mobile controls that support internal pagination also provide a feature called custom pagination. Normally, such controls require you to provide them all the data that they can display. Developers specify the total number of items that are in the list in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView.ItemCount%2A> property. The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView.ItemsPerPage%2A> property specifies how many items the control displays per page.
## Examples The following code example sets the number of items for each postback. This example is part of a larger example for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView> class overview.
[!code-csharp[MobileTextViewSample#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileTextViewSample/cs/Default.aspx#2)] [!code-vb[MobileTextViewSample#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/MobileTextViewSample/vb/Default.aspx#2)]

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event LoadItems As LoadItemsEventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when a control is custom-paginated and needs more data. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When control is custom-paginated, you do not explicitly bind the control. After pagination, the control raises this event, indicating what part of the data is required. The application can handle this event and bind the control with the required data.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to create custom pagination and call the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView.LoadItems> method to load a specified number of items per page.
> [!NOTE] > The following code sample uses the single-file code model and may not work correctly if copied directly into a code-behind file. This code sample must be copied into an empty text file that has an .aspx extension. For more information, see [ASP.NET Web Forms Page Code Model](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/81b13e7a-b95b-4285-906f-d2dd77411417).

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ Text { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.Text : string with get, set

Docs.summary: Sets or returns the text for the control. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks For information about the tags (such as \<b>) that <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView> supports in its <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView.Text%2A> property, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView> class discussion.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView.Text%2A> property can be specified by using the `Text` attribute, or as inner text. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView.Text%2A> property is specified in both ways, the inner text always takes precedence. However, if the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView.Text%2A> property is programmatically set, the inner text is automatically removed and the new setting takes precedence.
